is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">âˆ†</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">âˆ†</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Ï„</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">D</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">L</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Ï€</mi><mi is="true">Ï„</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">âˆ†</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">âˆ†</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Ï„</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where L<sup>2</sup><span> is the thickness of the material loaded on the <a href="/topics/engineering/aluminum-foil" title="Learn more about aluminum foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum foil</a>, which is easily obtained by a thickness gauge </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib58" name="bbib58" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib58"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>. D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> can be used to evaluate the electrochemical reaction kinetics. GITT test (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e) was performed and the calculated results are provided in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>f. The D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> value of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC is higher than that in monometallic sulfides, suggesting ion diffusion and conductivity improvement by the bimetallic sulfide solid solution. The result is in accord with the former rate capacity test and it demonstrates the strong diffusion ability of Na<sup>+</sup> in Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, which is conducive to rapid electrode reaction.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0135">Considering that Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC exhibits impressive performance as the <a href="/topics/engineering/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a> anode material in half-cell, we constructed sodium-ion full cells by pairing Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode with Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> (NVP) cathode. The NVP//Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC full cell was tested within the voltage range from 0.5 to 3.2â€‰V. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a, two broad peaks at 1.45 and 2.23â€‰V in cathodic sweep and 1.93 and 2.62â€‰v at anodic sweep appear in the CV test. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b shows the galvanostatic charge and discharge voltage profiles of the NVP//Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC full cell at 100â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. It displays a discharge voltage plateau between 1.6 and 2.0â€‰V. The full battery was charged and discharged at 200â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for 100 cycles and it delivers an average capacity of 240 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c). The NVP//Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC full cell exhibits a good rate capability: average specific capacity of 345, 270, 200, 100 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 100, 200, 1000, 2000â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0030" name="bfig0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d). The electrochemical performance of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC in half cell and full cell both demonstrate its promising application prospect for practical <a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-application" title="Learn more about energy storage application from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage application</a>.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr6.jpg" height="532" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (349KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (349KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) CV profiles of NVP//Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC obtained at a scan rate of 0.2â€‰mVâ€‰s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at the second cycle; (b) Galvanostatic charge and discharge voltage profiles of NVP//Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC at 100â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>; (c) Cycling performance of NVP//Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC at 200â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>; (d) Rate capacity of NVP//Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">In Basic on the in-depth study of the electrochemical reaction kinetics and de-/sodiation mechanism, the high performance and promising prospects as SIBs anode primarily comes from the following advantages: i) The coexistence of Co and Ni in the bimetallic sulfide solid solution generate abundant lattice defects, increase the active sites and modify the electronic structures, which significantly improve the charge transfer ability. ii) The waxberry-like structure derived from urchin-like precursors can effectively mitigate the volume changes during the de-/sodiation process and maintain the stability of the structure. iii) The in-situ generated nitrogen-doped carbon matrix and TMS are bonded together by strong S-C bonds that facilities the pseudocapacitive effects and cycling stability.</div></section><section id="sec0050"><h2 id="sect0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145"><span><span>This work presents a promising strategy for the recycling of spent NMC-811-type cathode material from <a href="/topics/engineering/lithium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about LIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">LIBs</a> into high-performance anodes for SIBs. A simple one-pot </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about hydrothermal method from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrothermal method</a><span> was employed to convert the waste cathode into CoNi-MOF, which can be then transformed into a bimetallic sulfide <a href="/topics/engineering/solid-solution" title="Learn more about solid solution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid solution</a><span> after carbonization and <a href="/topics/engineering/sulfidation" title="Learn more about sulfidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sulfidation</a><span> process. This innovative approach realizes the simple recovery of waste NMC-811-type cathode and improves the value of the recovered product. In addition, the introduction of bimetallic sulfide <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-solution" title="Learn more about solid solution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid solution</a> and the in-situ generation of nitrogen-doped carbon result in improved charge transfer and high Na</span></span></span></span><sup>+</sup> diffusion capabilities. The strong S-C bonds between nitrogen-doped carbon and TMS is favor for the remarkable cycling stability. As a result, the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode delivers high reversible specific capacity (622 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 200â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), outstanding rate capacity (370 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5000â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), and good cycling stability (330 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 1500 cycles at 5000â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>). This work demonstrates the feasibility of recycling spent <a href="/topics/materials-science/lithium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about LIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">LIBs</a> into high-performance anodes for SIBs, offering a promising solution to the spent LIBs disposal and the potential to turn waste into treasure.</span></div></section><section id="sec0055"><h2 id="sect0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150"><strong>Zhiwei Li:</strong> Experiment design, experiment, figures construction, manuscript writing, checked and revised the manuscript. <strong>Yuxiao Yang:</strong> SEM observation. <strong>Bo Wen:</strong> TEM observation. <strong>Xiaofeng Liu:</strong> experimental technical guidance. <strong>Yajun Wang, Fan Du and Mingming Ma:</strong> Investigation. <strong>Long Li:</strong> Review &amp; editing. <strong>Guorui Yang:</strong> Review &amp; editing, Funding acquisition. <strong>Shujiang Ding:</strong> Review &amp; editing.</div></section></div><section id="coi0005"><h2 id="sect0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of Competing Interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0005"><h2 id="sect0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">This work was supported by the <span id="gs1">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52273181</span></span></a>), <span id="gs2">Natural Science Foundation of Shaanxi Province</span>, China (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2020JQ-036</span></span></a>), <span id="gs3">Key Projects of Shaanxi Province</span>, China (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2021GXLH-Z-070</span></span></a>), and <span id="gs4">Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities of China</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">xzy022022004</span></span></a>). We would like to thank the Instrument Analysis Center of Xi â€™an Jiaotong University for their assistance in instrument testing.</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="sec0065"><h2 id="sect0095" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Shen, L. Cao, C.D. Rahn, C.-Y. Wang</div><div id="ref-id-sbref57" class="title text-m">Least squares galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (LS-GITT) for accurate solid phase diffusivity measurement</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">J. Electrochem. Soc., 160 (2013), pp. A1842-A1846</div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1149/2.084310jes" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Crossref</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Least%20squares%20galvanostatic%20intermittent%20titration%20technique%20%20for%20accurate%20solid%20phase%20diffusivity%20measurement&amp;publication_year=2013&amp;author=Z.%20Shen&amp;author=L.%20Cao&amp;author=C.D.%20Rahn&amp;author=C.-Y.%20Wang" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-sbref57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (19)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1383586624015168"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Review on the sustainable recycling of spent ternary lithium-ion batteries: From an eco-friendly and efficient perspective</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Separation and Purification Technology</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Direct regeneration of SNCM is to restore the electrode material that the structure and function have failed or declined [35,36]. In addition, some pretreatment including roasting, defluorination and carbon removal can be used to enhance the recovery of valuable metals in SNCM [37â€“40]. Although the current treatment methods for SNCM electrode materials are various and relatively mature, however, these treatment methods for electrode materials are usually obtained under laboratory conditions.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010">The overall crushing of spent ternary lithium-ion batteries (SNCM) makes the mix of the anode and cathode electrode materials. Multiple separation not only wastes energy, causes secondary pollution but also fails to achieve the excellent separation of the valuable component. Therefore, this paper reviewed the recycling methods of SNCM from three aspects, including the single recycling of anode electrode materials, the single recycling of cathode electrode materials and the overall collaborative recycling of anode and cathode electrode materials. The necessity of high-purity separation of the anode and cathode electrode materials was discussed by evaluating the difference between single recycling and overall collaborative recycling. A process that used collaborative reclaim to realize efficient and green resource utilization of electrode materials was proposed based on the review. In this process, the mixed electrode materials were first divided into rich cathode-poor anode materials and rich anode-poor cathode materials by flotation. Two kinds of materials were regenerated to prepare NCM. The recovery of the cathode was enhanced through the reduction properties of the anode. The electrochemical properties of the regenerated anode were enhanced by the in-situ self-utilization behavior of the cathode. The recovery process was optimized by simplifying the process and improving efficiency. The economic and green of the recovery process was ensured by treating the SNCM with readily available and environmentally friendly agents.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1385894724043249"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Research on green recycling of lithium-ion batteries cathode waste powder</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Chemical Engineering Journal</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">The results showed that Li was selectively recovered in citrate solution with a leaching efficiency of 99.7 %. Li and co-workers [26] used a one-step hydrothermal technique to convert waste NCM into CoNi-MOF, which was then carbonized and vulcanized to prepare a bimetallic sulfide solid solution. The experimental procedure is shown in Fig. 5d.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have brought undeniable technological innovation to electronic devices, and the widespread use of these batteries has led to significant production of raw materials. However, these materials need to be properly treated to eliminate the negative environmental impact of toxic raw materials. Recycling of such batteries requires necessary and appropriate solutions. Therefore, this work reviews national and international treatment methods of cathode materials commercially available in recent years, such as hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, and direct regeneration, supplemented by studies of external field process and electrochemical method, which are innovative and environmentally friendly methods of recycling. It also includes the recycling characteristics and failure mechanism of spent LiFePO<sub>4</sub>, LiNi<sub>x</sub>Co<sub>y</sub>Mn<sub>z</sub> (x&nbsp;+&nbsp;y&nbsp;+&nbsp;z&nbsp;=&nbsp;1), and LiM<sub>x</sub>O<sub>2x</sub> (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;Ni, Co, Mn), respectively. Additionally, considering the future challenges and opportunities of post-consumer LIBs recycling, this work aims to provide a valuable reference for LIBs recycling.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2468023024004346"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">g-C&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;N&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt; confined Sb&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;Se&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; as high-performance anode towards rapid and stable Na-ion storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Surfaces and Interfaces</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">For this reason, sodium ionic batteries (SIBs) have attracted much attention as high-capacity and low-cost next-generation secondary batteries [1,2]. Although SIBs and LIBs have similar working principles, traditional graphite anodes with larger radius of Na+ greatly obstruct the reversible insertion/deintercalation process of Na+ [3â€“5]. To further accelerate the commercial application process of SIBs, there is an urgent need to exploit anode materials with excellent stability, superb reversible capacity, and long cycle life.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara007">Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> is considered a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its abundant reserves, low cost, and high theoretical capacity. Nevertheless, significant volume changes and slow electron transfer kinetics significantly limit its rate capability and cycle stability. In this work, we constructed g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub>-coated Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> nanorods (Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub>) through the hydrothermal method and subsequent thermal treatment to enhance kinetics and achieve high cycle stability. The coating enhances the structure stability, insertion/extraction reversibility of Na<sup>+</sup>, and electrochemical reaction activity. Benefiting from the unique structure and composition, Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> (8 wt%) nanorod exhibits excellent rate properties with high desodiation capacities of 376.7, 345.5, 336.1, 322.7, 301.4, and 275.0 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. Even at 5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> (8 wt%) exhibits high cycle stability with a capacity retention of approximately 86.7% after 600 cycles. Ex-situ XRD and XPS results confirm that the introduction of g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> on the surface of Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> inhibits the volumetric expansion and electrode pulverization of Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>, thereby improving the structural stability of the composite material, resulting in an excellent electrochemical capability of Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> nanorods. Sb<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>@g-C<sub>3</sub>N<sub>4</sub> nanorods show massive potential as an anode material for the next-generation high-performance SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0021979724000705"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Constructing Coâ€“Nâ€“C coordination in Co&lt;inf&gt;9&lt;/inf&gt;S&lt;inf&gt;8&lt;/inf&gt; embedded N,S-codoped carbon nanotube as an advanced electrode for supercapacitor and Na-ion battery</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Colloid and Interface Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Yolk-shell-structured transition metal sulfides (TMSs)/carbon nanocomposites are highly desirable in advanced energy storage system, such as sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) and supercapacitors (SCs). Nevertheless, practical applications are still prevented by the loose attachment of TMSs with carbon caused by conversion stress, the aggregation of TMSs nanoparticles and the sluggish ion transport caused by high crystallinity of carbon. Here, the disperse hollow Co<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> nanoparticles encapsulated into N,S-codoped carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with poor crystallinity through Co<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">N<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bond was synthesized (CS-NSCNT) to overcome the above obstacles. The designed CS-NSCNT can provide the short diffusion path and prevent the huge volume expansion of conversion reaction. Moreover, the established Co<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">N<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bond endows the strong interaction and regulates the electronic structure thus promote the stability and rate performance effectively. The CS-NSCNT SCsâ€™s electrode delivers a high specific capacitance of 1150 F g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, with a high cycling life stability and rate performance. For SIBs, the CS-NSCNT cathode demonstrates an initial reversible capacity of 475 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and an excellent rate performance with a capacity retention of 53&nbsp;% at 10 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. This work may satisfy the long-stability, high-capacitance/capacity, high-power/energy density application requirements of future applications.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X23024714"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Recycling valuable materials from the cathodes of spent lithium-ion batteries: A comprehensive review</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Journal of Energy Storage</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">Some other novel methods were used to recycle valuable metals, or to recover the electrochemical performance of the spent cathodes including hydrothermal, reciprocal ternary molten salt (RTMS), centrifugal gravity concentration, rapid thermal radiation, and atomic layer deposition (ALD). Z. Li et al. [138] developed a hydrothermal process to transform the spent NMC811 cathode to CoNi-MOF structure. A Co0.11Ni0.89S@N-doped carbon composite resembling a waxberry was synthesized as an anode material to be utilized sodium-ion batteries (Fig. 26).</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-4-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-4" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0190">A large deal of knowledge about recycling offers hope for the future in this day and age when trash resulting from several systems or items is a major concern. This article compiles and presents to the readers the most recent research on the recycling of active elements in Li-ion batteries, the widely used energy storage devices in recent years. At this stage, as a critical examination of the literature, current techniques and procedures for recycling frequently used Li-ion battery types, including LCO, LFP, LMO, NMC, and NCA batteries, are discussed. In general, data on the recycling effectiveness of the three types of recycling processesâ€”pyrometallurgy, hydrometallurgy, and mechanical separationâ€”as well as any reuse of recovered materials have been collated and presented. It is intended that this review article would aid readers' studies and researches because the significance of recycling used Li-ion batteries is growing every day.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1463926224000761"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A systematic review of efficient recycling for the cathode materials of spent lithium-ion batteries: process intensification technologies beyond traditional methods</span></span></a></h3><div>2023, Green Chemistry</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-5-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-5" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom">With the increasing use and the consequent retirement of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), there has been an upsurge in spent LIBs, posing significant challenges to energy, resources, and the environment, which has led to the necessity to recycle spent LIBs. For the recovery of valuable components in cathode materials, traditional hydrometallurgical and pyrometallurgical methods are not conducive to the sustainable development of the environment, making it crucial to explore lithium-ion battery (LIB) recovery technologies beyond traditional methods. This paper focuses on introducing intensification technologies that are beyond the traditional methods, including external field intensification technologies (in the fields of acoustics, optics, electricity, and magnetism), novel solvent-based intensification technologies, direct recovery technologies, and potential development technologies. From the perspective of process intensification, the process flow, principle, effect, and scope of application of various recovery technologies are systematically summarized. Furthermore, the advantages of these advanced recovery methods and the current challenges faced by them are discussed to propose the potential research direction of the recovery technology of lithium-ion battery cathode materials, which is of significant importance for the sustainable development of the global new energy industry, the maintenance of ecological balance, and the circular utilization of mineral resources, such as lithium, nickel, and cobalt.</div></div></div></div></li></ul><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-secondary large-alternative button-alternative-icon-left" href="http://www.scopus.com/scopus/inward/citedby.url?partnerID=10&amp;rel=3.0.0&amp;eid=2-s2.0-85154588894&amp;md5=485e8d89593a1a4ceaa99418a5dde7f0" target="_blank" id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">View all citing articles on Scopus</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></a></div></div></section></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S0925838823016316"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">Â© 2023 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right u-padding-s-top"><aside class="RelatedContent u-clr-grey8" aria-label="Related data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=recommended-articles:type=close"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text"><h2 class="section-title u-h4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a></div></li><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-block"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article2-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1385894720340821" title="Rational synthesis of uniform yolkâ€“shell Niâ€“Fe bimetallic sulfide nanoflakes@porous carbon nanospheres as advanced anodes for high-performance potassium-/sodium-ion batteries"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Rational synthesis of uniform yolkâ€“shell Niâ€“Fe bimetallic sulfide nanoflakes@porous carbon Journal, Volume 417, 2021, Article 127963</div></div><div class="authors"><span>Su Hyun</span> <span>Yang</span>, â€¦, <span>Yun Chan</span> <span>Kang</span></div></div><div class="buttons"><a target="_blank" rel="nofollow" aria-describedby="recommended-articles-article2-title"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 35 32" height="20" class="icon icon-pdf-multicolor"><path d="M7 .362h17.875l6.763 6.1V31.64H6.948V16z" stroke="#000" stroke-width=".703" fill="#fff"></path><path d="M.167 2.592H22.39V9.72H.166z" fill="#da0000"></path><path fill="#fff9f9" d="M5.97 3.638h1.62c1.053 1.228-1.462.008-1.06-.316-1.45-1.23-1.45h-.347m-.977-.94h1.03c1.68 0 2.523.586 2.534 2.39.01 1.688-.607 2.4-2.534 2.4h-1.03V3.64m4.305 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a></div></li><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-none"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',

        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
