Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC exhibits remarkable <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span> with an initial <a href="/topics/engineering/coulomb-efficiency" title="Learn more about coulomb efficiency from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coulomb efficiency</a> of up to 87 %, a high reversible specific capacity (622 mAh g</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), excellent rate performance (370 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5000&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) and stable cycles (89.1 % capacity retention after 1500 cycles).</div></section><section id="sec0010"><h2 id="sect0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental</h2><section id="sec0015"><h3 id="sect0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Preparation of acid-leaching filtrate</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span>The spent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lithium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about LIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">LIBs</a> were soaked into 10&nbsp;wt% Nacl solution for 24&nbsp;h to fully release the remaining energy and then manually dismantled into four parts, including cathode, anode, separator, and metal case. The cathodes were annealed at 450&nbsp;Â°C for 1&nbsp;h under a H</span><sub>2</sub><span>/Ar <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/gas-flow" title="Learn more about gas flow from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">gas flow</a><span><span>. After annealing, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/cathode-material" title="Learn more about cathode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cathode materials</a> were mechanically stirred in </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/deionized-water" title="Learn more about deionized water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deionized water</a> to separate them from the Al foil, and the resulting black powder was collected by filtration and drying </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>. The acid leaching process was performed using the following conditions: H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> concentration of 1&nbsp;M, H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub><span> concentration of 1&nbsp;vol%, temperature of 65&nbsp;Â°C, stirring speed of 400&nbsp;rpm, <a href="/topics/engineering/pulp-density" title="Learn more about pulp density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pulp density</a> of 40&nbsp;g&nbsp;L</span><sup>âˆ’&nbsp;1</sup>, and leaching time of 2&nbsp;h. Following the reaction, the leach liquor was diluted thrice and the pH was adjusted to an appropriate value with Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub><span><span>. The acid-leaching filtrate was then obtained by filtration. The composition of the leach liquor was analyzed using <a href="/topics/materials-science/elemental-analysis" title="Learn more about elemental analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental analysis</a> and inductively coupled plasma-optical emission </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/spectroscopy" title="Learn more about spectrometry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">spectrometry</a> (ICP-OES).</span></div></section><section id="sec0020"><h3 id="sect0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Synthesis of the CoNi-MOF precursor from spent NMC-811 cathodes</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">A mixture of 30&nbsp;ml acid leaching filtrate and 30&nbsp;ml&nbsp;N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) was prepared. 1.5&nbsp;g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, MW 40000) and 0.3&nbsp;g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid were added to the mixed solution with vigorous stirring for 30&nbsp;min to form a homogeneous solution, which was then transferred into a 100&nbsp;ml Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at 160&nbsp;Â°C for 15&nbsp;h. After the reaction, the green precipitates were collected through centrifugation, washed with ethanol, and dried in vacuum at 80&nbsp;Â°C for 12&nbsp;h.</div></section><section id="sec0025"><h3 id="sect0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Synthesis of Ni-MOF and Co-MOF</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">In contrast, the Ni-MOF and Co-MOF were synthesized in the same way as CoNi-MOF and the source of nickel and cobalt were lithium <a href="/topics/materials-science/nickelate" title="Learn more about nickelate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nickelate</a><span> and lithium cobalt <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxide-compound" title="Learn more about oxides from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxides</a>, respectively.</span></div></section><section id="sec0030"><h3 id="sect0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Preparation of metal sulfide/N-doped carbon composites</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065"><span>The CoNi-MOF, Ni-MOF, and Co-MOF were subjected to <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization</a><span><span> in an <a href="/topics/engineering/ar-atmosphere" title="Learn more about Ar atmosphere from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ar atmosphere</a> at 500&nbsp;Â°C with a </span><a href="/topics/engineering/ramp-rate" title="Learn more about ramp rate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ramp rate</a> of 2&nbsp;Â°C&nbsp;min</span></span><sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, followed by holding for 1&nbsp;h. The obtained black powders were mixed with <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/thiourea" title="Learn more about thiourea from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thiourea</a> with a mass ratio of 1:3 and carbonized in an Ar atmosphere at 600&nbsp;Â°C for 2&nbsp;h with a ramp rate of 2&nbsp;Â°C&nbsp;min</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>. The final products obtained after this thermal treatment were labeled as Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC, respectively.</div></section><section id="sec0035"><h3 id="sect0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.5. Materials characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070"><span>The structure of the obtained products was determined by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 ADVANC) with Cu-K <a href="/topics/engineering/alpha-radiation" title="Learn more about Î± radiation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Î± radiation</a><span>. The morphology and microstructure of the products were investigated by field-emission scanning microscopy (FESEM, Gemini SEM 500), <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a><span> (TEM, Talos L120C G2), and high-resolution <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (HRTEM). The </span></span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/surface-elemental-composition" title="Learn more about surface elemental composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface elemental composition</a><span><span> of the products was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis (XPS, Thermo Fisher ESCALAB Xi+). <a href="/topics/engineering/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> were collected on an InVia Qontor (RENISHAW). </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about Thermal gravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Thermal gravimetric analysis</a><span> (TGA) was conducted on a METTLER TOLEDO TGA/DSC3 in an Ar atmosphere with a <a href="/topics/engineering/rate-of-heating" title="Learn more about heating rate of from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heating rate of</a> 10&nbsp;Â°C from room temperature to 800&nbsp;Â°C. The specific surface area was determined by the nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements (ASAP 2020 Plus HD88) based on the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) multipoint method. The metallic element contents were determined by the ICP test on an ICPE-9000.</span></span></div></section><section id="sec0040"><h3 id="sect0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.6. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075"><span>The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> was evaluated in a half cell using a CR2025 coin-type cell. The working electrode was prepared by mixing the active material (Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC), Super P, and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene</a><span> difluoride (PVDF) in N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP) with a weight ratio of 8:1:1. The resulting slurry was coated on a <a href="/topics/engineering/copper-foil" title="Learn more about copper foil from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">copper foil</a> and dried at 80&nbsp;Â°C in vacuum for 12&nbsp;h. The coated copper foil was cut into discs with a mass loading of 0.8â€“1.2&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span></span><sup>âˆ’2</sup><span>. CR2025 coin-type half cells were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox, in which <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> foil and Whatman glass fiber were used as counter electrodes and separator respectively. NaPF</span><sub>6</sub> (1&nbsp;mol&nbsp;L<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) dissolved in DIGLYME was used as the electrolyte and the content was 80&nbsp;Î¼L. Galvanostatic charge/discharge performances were tested between 0.2 and 3&nbsp;V (vs Na<sup>+</sup><span>/Na) with the Neware-5 V10 mA system and before <a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current density</a> was applied, a current density of 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup><span> was applied in the first five cycles to activate the <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a>. Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT) measurements were carried out to determine the Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of active material. During the test, the voltage window was set to 0.2â€“3&nbsp;V, the current density was 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, the pulse time was 10&nbsp;min, and the <a href="/topics/engineering/relaxation-time" title="Learn more about relaxation time from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">relaxation time</a> was 40&nbsp;min. And the loading mass for the testing electrodes is in the range of 0.8â€“1.2&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span><sup>âˆ’2</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic voltammetry</a><span> (CV) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) were measured on an electrochemical workstation (CHI660E). All electrochemical tests were carried out at room temperature.</span></span></div></section></section><section id="sec0045"><h2 id="sect0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0080"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a> illustrates the synthesis of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, starting from the precursor CoNi-MOF, which was prepared by recycling Co and Ni elements from spent NMC-811 cathode. The spent LIBs were first discharged in salt water and then manually disassembled into four components, namely the cathode, anode, metal case, and separator (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a><span>). After thermal treatment and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ultrasonic-processing" title="Learn more about ultrasonic processing from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ultrasonic processing</a>, the cathode powders were separated from the Al foils, and then dissolved in solutions of H</span><sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> and H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> to obtain leachates of Co, Ni, and Mn. The concentration of the Ni, Mn and Co leachate was detected to be 18.56&nbsp;g&nbsp;L<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 2.36&nbsp;g&nbsp;L<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, and 2.42&nbsp;g&nbsp;L<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, for Ni, Mn, and Co, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>). CoNi-MOF was synthesized using a facile solvothermal method with the filtrate as the source of Ni<sup>2+</sup> and Co<sup>2+</sup><span>, while 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid served as the organic linker. The resulting CoNi-MOF was dissolved in <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nitric-acid" title="Learn more about nitric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nitric acid</a>, and the content of metal elements in the product was determined by ICP-OES. No manganese was detected in the as-synthesized CoNi-MOF, and the concentrations of Ni and Co elements were found to be 3.99&nbsp;g&nbsp;L</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 0.541&nbsp;g&nbsp;L<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a><span><span><span>). The <a href="/topics/engineering/molar-ratio" title="Learn more about molar ratio from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar ratio</a><span> of Ni to Co of the CoNi-MOF was determined to be 8:1, consistent with that in the leach liquor. The CoNi-MOF precursor was then subjected to carbonization in an <a href="/topics/engineering/ar-atmosphere" title="Learn more about Ar atmosphere from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ar atmosphere</a> at 500 ÂºC to yield the CoNi@NC composite. Subsequently, </span></span><a href="/topics/materials-science/vulcanization" title="Learn more about vulcanization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vulcanization</a> of the composite with </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/thiourea" title="Learn more about thiourea from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thiourea</a> was carried out in an Ar atmosphere at 600 ÂºC, resulting in the formation of the Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC composite. NiS@NC and CoS@NC were similarly synthesized using LiNiO<sub>2</sub> and LiCoO<sub>2</sub><span> cathodes, respectively. The <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/thiourea" title="Learn more about thiourea from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thiourea</a> served as both a sulfur and nitrogen source, facilitating the production of metal sulfides and nitrogen-doped carbon.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr1.jpg" height="301" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (173KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (173KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0005"><p id="sp0005"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Illustration of the synthetic procedure of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC from spent LIBs.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085">As exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a and d, the CoNi-MOF exhibits a uniform three-dimensional urchin-like structure with an average size of 5â€‰Âµm. The surface structure of these spheres is composed of many acicular crystalline nanowires with sharp tips, stacked uniformly on the surface. The Ni-MOF reveals a consistent spherical shape with a diameter of 1.5â€‰Âµm, and its surface shows sheet-like structures in addition to the spherical structure, as observed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4a</span></span></a>. In contrast, the Co-MOF displays a unique sphere structure composed of hollow triangular tubes, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4b</span></span></a>. These observations suggest that the Ni-MOF tends to form a spherical structure during the coordination reaction, while the Co-MOF tends to adopt a radial tubular architecture. Therefore, the CoNi-MOF composite exhibits a distinctive structure, featuring a ball-shaped core and acicular crystalline nanowires arranged uniformly on the surface. After the carbonization treatment, the length of the nanowires on the surface decreased, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>b and e. During the subsequent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sulfidation" title="Learn more about sulfidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sulfidation</a> process, these nanowires underwent further evolution into cone-shaped protrusions, which resulted in the formation of a waxberry-like structure, as depicted in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>c and f. The average diameter of the obtained samples decreased to 4â€‰Âµm compared to the CoNi-MOF precursor. <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about TEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TEM</a> images (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g and h) exhibit a clear lattice fringe with interplanar of 0.29â€‰nm and 0.258â€‰nm on the edge of the spikes which correspond to the (100) and (101) plane of the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S phase. The elemental mapping presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0010" name="bfig0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>i reveals a <a href="/topics/engineering/homogeneous-distribution" title="Learn more about homogeneous distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">homogeneous distribution</a> of Ni, Co, C, and S elements throughout the waxberry-like composite. The morphology of the Ni-MOF and Co-MOF sulfides are depicted in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4c and d</span></span></a>. The NiS@NC maintains the same morphology as Ni-MOF, with a size of 1â€‰Âµm. On the other hand, CoS@NC displays a spherical structure enveloped by a layer of small balls, with the internal triangular tubes remaining intact.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr2.jpg" height="566" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (772KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (772KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="sp0010"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. SEM images of CoNi-MOF (a and d), CoNi@C (b and e), and Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC (c and f); TEM images (g) and <a href="/topics/materials-science/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> image (h) of Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC; Elemental mapping (i) of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><span>The phase purity and crystal structure of the synthesized products were characterized by <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a>. As illustrated in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5a</span></span></a><span>, the XRD patterns of NiCo-MOF are similar to those of Ni-MOF, indicating that the introduction of Co did not alter the crystal structure of Ni-MOF. The high <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a> of Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC is confirmed by the sharp diffraction peaks observed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span><span>a, which can be well indexed to NiS (PDF#75-0613). Notably, the diffraction peaks corresponding to (102) and (101) <a href="/topics/engineering/lattice-plane" title="Learn more about lattice planes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice planes</a> are slightly shifted, which is a typical characteristic of </span><a href="/topics/engineering/solid-solution" title="Learn more about solid solutions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid solutions</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. The XRD patterns of CoNi@C, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC are presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a><span>. The XRD pattern of CoNi@C corresponds to metallic nickel (PDF#65-0380), indicating that Ni and Co were reduced to their metallic forms during the <a href="/topics/engineering/carbonization-process" title="Learn more about carbonization process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization process</a><span>. The diffraction peaks of NiS@NC and CoS@NC match well with the standard patterns of NiS (PDF#65-3686) and CoS (PDF#75-0605), respectively. To ensure complete carbonization of CoNi-MOF in the Ar atmosphere, <a href="/topics/materials-science/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about thermal gravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal gravimetric analysis</a> (TGA) was performed and the results are presented in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6a</span></span></a><span>. The sample weight slightly decreased between 100â€‰Â°C and 350â€‰Â°C due to the removal of water and <a href="/topics/materials-science/organic-solvents" title="Learn more about organic solvents from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">organic solvents</a>. A significant weight loss occurred between 350â€‰Â°C and 450â€‰Â°C, which was attributed to the decomposition of organic ligands. Based on the TGA curve, the carbonization temperature was determined to be 500â€‰Â°C. The TGA curves of Ni-MOF and Co-MOF are shown in the </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6b and c</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr3.jpg" height="462" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (528KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (528KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) XRD patterns of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC; (b) Raman spectra of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC; (c) The adsorptionâ€“desorption isotherms of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC; (d) Full XPS spectra of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC; High-resolution XPS spectra of (e) Ni 2p and (f) N 1â€‰s.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095"><span><a href="/topics/engineering/raman-spectrum" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> of Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC, depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b, indicate the presence of two forms of carbon in these composites. Two strong peaks can be observed at 1334â€‰cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 1566â€‰cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, corresponding to the D band of <a href="/topics/engineering/disordered-carbon" title="Learn more about disordered carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">disordered carbon</a><span> and the G band of <a href="/topics/engineering/graphitic-carbon" title="Learn more about graphitic carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitic carbon</a>, respectively. The intensity ratio of the D band to the G band (I</span></span><sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span>) can be employed to evaluate the <a href="/topics/engineering/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a> degree in the samples </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>. The I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> values are calculated to be 1.05, 1.00 and 1.14 for Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC, respectively. It has been reported that metallic Ni <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> demonstrate higher catalytic ability than metallic Co, which were formed during the carbonization, indicating that the high Ni content facilitate the generation of graphitic carbon </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a><span>. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis was conducted to survey the surface area and <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-structure" title="Learn more about pore structures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore structures</a>, as shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption curves indicate that all of the three composites exhibit mesoporous structure with a typical IV type isotherm <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>. The BET surface areas of the of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC are 12â€‰m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, 23â€‰m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>âˆ’1,</sup> and 27â€‰m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> respectively. It is worth noting that Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC has the smallest specific surface area among the three composites due to its largest particle size.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">The surface chemical composition and elemental status of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC can be characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Full XPS spectrum illustrates the co-existence of Ni, Co, S, C, and N elements (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d). The O 1â€‰s peak at 531.2â€‰eV can be ascribed to the oxygen adsorbed on the surface <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. Based on the high-resolution spectra of Ni in Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e), the peaks at 873.7â€‰eV and 856.1a eV correspond to Ni<sup>2+</sup> 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and Ni<sup>2+</sup> 2p<sub>3/2</sub> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, while two satellite peaks can be observed at 879.6â€‰eV and 861.8â€‰eV. When compared with the binding energies of NiS@NC, the peaks pertained to Ni<sup>2+</sup> shifted negatively in the Ni 2p spectra owing to the introduction of Co. In the spectra of Co 2p (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7a</span></span></a>), the peaks at 797.2â€‰eV and 781.4â€‰eV are assigned to Co<sup>2+</sup> 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and Co<sup>2+</sup> 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, respectively with two satellite peaks centering at 802.9â€‰eV and 786.1â€‰eV <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. The spectra of Ni 2p and Co 2p reveals the existence of Ni<sup>2+</sup> and Co<sup>2+</sup> in the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC. The N 1â€‰s spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0015" name="bfig0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f) demonstrates the presence of three different forms of nitrogen relative to graphitic N (401.1â€‰eV), pyrrolic N (400e V) and pyridinic N (398.7â€‰eV) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, which underlines the successful formation of N-doped carbon in Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC. The abundant pyridinic N in Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC could create numerous extrinsic defects and active sites in carbon that would contribute to the pseudocapacitive sodium storage, leading to fast reaction kinetic and good rate capability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. S 2p spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7b</span></span></a>) presents two peaks at 162.8â€‰eV and 161.5â€‰eV attributed to S 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and S 2p<sub>3/2</sub> respectively. The peak at 165.4â€‰eV verifies the presence of strong S-C bonds between the sulfide and carbon matrix. In addition, the peaks at 169.0â€‰eV could be assigned to S-O. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7c</span></span></a>, the C 1â€‰s spectra can be deconvoluted into three peaks corresponding to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C-OH, C-N, and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" alt="double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C-C, located at 288â€‰eV, 285.8â€‰eV, and 284.8â€‰eV, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. The XPS spectra shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a> strongly support the successful preparation of NiS@NC and CoS@NC. It can be observed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8b</span></span></a> that Co<sup>2+</sup> and Co<sup>3+</sup> exist simultaneously in CoS@NC. And this may be due to the fact that part of Co<sup>2+</sup> was oxidized to Co<sup>3+</sup><span> by the oxygen adsorbed on the surface of the material during the <a href="/topics/engineering/vulcanization-process" title="Learn more about vulcanization process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vulcanization process</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">To investigate the electrochemical performance of the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC composite as anode material in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>, a series of measurements were performed in a half-cell configuration. The electrochemical reactivity of Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC for sodium storage was tested by <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> measurements. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a presents the initial CV curves of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC at a scan rate of 0.2â€‰mVâ€‰s<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span> in the voltage range of 0.01â€“3.0â€‰V. In the first cathodic scan, a sharp reduction peak at 0.79â€‰V was observed, which can be attributed to the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of <a href="/topics/engineering/solid-electrolyte-interface" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte interface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte interface</a> (SEI) layer </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a><span>. The peak at 1.09â€‰V is assigned to the reduction of metal sulfides to Ni and Co. During the anodic scan, three <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> peaks were detected at 1.9â€‰V, 1.8â€‰V, and 1.3â€‰V associated with the oxidation of Ni and Co to their metal sulfides </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>. The small anodic peak at 0.08â€‰V is caused by the insertion and extraction of sodium in carbon <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. The position of the reduction and oxidation peaks in the following cycles remained unchanged, indicating the excellent cycling stability of the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b describes the charge-discharge curves for different cycles at 200â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> in the voltage window of 0.2â€“3â€‰V for the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode. The de-/sodiation voltage plateaus are consistent with the CV analysis mentioned above.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr4.jpg" height="455" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (502KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (502KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) CV profiles of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC obtained at a scan rate of 0.2â€‰mVâ€‰s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>; (b) Charge-discharge profiles at 200â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>; (c) Cycling performance, (d) rate capacity and, (e) long cycle performance of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">As described in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c, the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode demonstrates an initial discharge capacity of 781 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and high initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 87 %. The observed initial capacity loss is due to the formation of the SEI layer, accompanied by the decomposition of electrolyte and several irreversible reactions. The small specific surface area of the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode resulted in a higher initial ICE compared to materials with a larger contact area, which could cause more SEI layer formation and lower ICE <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>. Impressively, it delivers a discharge capacity of 649 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> in the second cycle and a discharge capacity of 622 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> is retained after the 100th cycles with 95.8 % capacity retention. In contrast, NiS@NC and CoS@NC deliver lower initial discharge capacities of 556 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 592 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><sub>,</sub> respectively. The SEM images of the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC electrode before and after cycling were obtained, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>. It can be observed that the morphology of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC remains intact, and no agglomeration or structural collapse is detected after 100 cycles at 200â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. The excellent cycling stability can be attributed to the uniform waxberry-like structure and the strong bond between sulfide and carbon matrix, which alleviates the effect of volume change during the de-/sodiation process.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d shows the rate capacity of the samples. The Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC possess superior rate performance compared with NiS@NC and CoS@NC, which delivers average discharge capacities of 651, 591, 463, 415, and 330 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 100, 200, 500, 1000, and 5000â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively. In addition, when the current turns from 5000â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> back to 200â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, a discharge capacity of 562 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span><span> can be reserved, indicating its fast <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> kinetics and good cycling stability. In contrast, NiS@NC and CoS@NC exhibit lower discharge capacities, particularly at </span><a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current densities from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current densities</a><span>. As fast charge-discharge capacity is a crucial index for <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about batteries from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">batteries</a>, long-term performance tests were conducted under high current density. </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0020" name="bfig0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>e shows the cycling performance of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC at 5000â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. The Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode exhibits a stable capacity of 370 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and maintains a favorable reversible capacity of 330 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> with 89.1 % capacity retention after 1500 cycles. In contrast, NiS@NC and CoS@NC exhibit lower specific capacities and worse cycling stability at a current density of 5000â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, as compared to Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Supporting information</span></span></a>) lists the comparison of electrochemical performances between Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC and other Co-/Ni- based metal sulfides as <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a> anode. Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC shows better sodium storage performance both in cycling performance and rate capacity.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0120">To further investigate the reaction kinetics of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode, pseudocapacitive analysis was conducted. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b, CV curves at different scan rates were obtained. With the increase in scanning speed, the reduction peak migrated toward low potential, while the oxidation peak migrated toward high potential. This phenomenon can be ascribed to polarization <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>. The pseudocapacitive contribution during charge-discharge progress can be analyzed according to the equation:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0005" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mspace width=&quot;1em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BD;</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></mrow></msup><mspace width=&quot;1em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="11.971ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 5154.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1000,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2679,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3209,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BD"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(541,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g><g is="true"></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î½</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></msup><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î½</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">b</mi></mrow></msup><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where i is the measured current and Î½ is the scan rate. The b-value ranges from 0.5 to 1 can be obtained by plotting log (i) versus log (Î½) and when b =â€‰0.5, the cell reaction is a diffusion control process, whereas b =â€‰1 means a capacitive control process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>. The b-values of the three main peaks are 0.82, 0.94, and 0.98 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c), respectively, indicating the fact that the diffusion control and capacitive control both exist in the process of charge-discharge. The specific contribution of the two different mechanisms can be further calculated according to the equation:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0010" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mspace width=&quot;1em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mfenced open=&quot;(&quot; close=&quot;)&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BD;</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;badbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3BD;</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width=&quot;1em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="24.056ex" height="3.009ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 10357.6 1295.7" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1000,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1345,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28" x="0" y="0"></use><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-56"></use></g></g><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29" x="1159" y="0"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2894,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3950,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4925,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BD"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5678,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(6679,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7654,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3BD"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(541,362)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g><g is="true"></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î½</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î½</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><mrow is="true"><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace><mi is="true">i</mi><mrow is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi></mrow></mfenced></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î½</mi><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">+</mo><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î½</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup><mspace width="1em" is="true"></mspace></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where i(V) is the current at a certain potential and Î½ is the scan rate. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12e</span></span></a> demonstrates a capacitive contribution as high as 90.2 % at the scan rate of 1â€‰mVâ€‰s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and the capacitive contributions at other scan rates are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12a-d</span></span></a>, which are higher than that of NiS@NC and CoS@NC (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a>). The capacitive contributions at different scan rates are summarized in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>d and it is obvious that the capacitive contribution increases as the scan rate increases. The pseudocapacitive process is characterized by fast <a href="/topics/engineering/electrochemical-kinetics" title="Learn more about electrochemical kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical kinetics</a> which can significantly enhance the electrochemical performance of batteries </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib56" name="bbib56" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib56"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. The results of the pseudocapacitive analysis reveal that the charge storage in Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC is primarily attributed to the pseudocapacitive process, which accounts for its outstanding rate capability and cycling stability.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr5.jpg" height="928" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (680KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (680KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0925838823016316-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a) EIS spectra of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC; (b) CV curves of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC at different scan rates range from 0.2 to 1â€‰mVâ€‰s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>; (c) Log i vs. Log v plots of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC; (d) Capacitive contribution at distinct scan rates; (e) Charge-discharge GITT curves at 200â€‰mAâ€‰g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> of Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC; (f) Log of the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficient in Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC, NiS@NC, and CoS@NC during the discharge and charge.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125"><span>Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) and Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT) were conducted to acquire deep insight into the excellent sodium storage performance. <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> measurement demonstrates that the Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode possesses a smaller charge-transfer resistance (R<sub>ct</sub>) of 16.92â€‰Î© compared to NiS@NC anode (34.25â€‰Î©) and CoS@NC anode (28.3â€‰Î©) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0025" name="bfig0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a), indicating that Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode has faster Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-kinetics" title="Learn more about diffusion kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion kinetics</a> within the electrode. The EIS spectra of the Co</span><sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub>S@NC anode obtained after different numbers of cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#sec0065" name="bsec0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="sec0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a>) illustrates that the R<sub>ct</sub><span><span> value decreases progressively with the increase of cycle number. It is worth noting that a smaller Rct value implies faster interfacial <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electron transport from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron transport</a> and is associated with abundant ion transport channels and good electron conductivity, indicating excellent cycle stability. The addition of a small amount of Co </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/doping-additives" title="Learn more about dopant from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">dopant</a> in NiS has the function to increase the active sites and generate abundant lattice defects, leading to improved charge transfer kinetics and enhanced electrochemical activity </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>. The coexistence of Co and Ni in the bimetallic sulfide solid solution modifies the electronic structures and the coordination environment of active atoms, which significantly improves the charge transfer ability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib57" name="bbib57" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib57"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>. Therefore, the Co<sub>0.11</sub>Ni<sub>0.89</sub><span>S@NC anode is endowed with good <a href="/topics/engineering/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a> and cycling stability.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">GITT has been widely accepted as a convincing and efficient electrochemical test method to obtain the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> (D</span><sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup>) in solid-state electrode materials. The D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> can be calculated by the following formula:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0015" class="formula"><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" time from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">relaxation time</a>, m</span><sub>B</sub> is the mass of the active materials, M<sub>B</sub><span> is the <a href="/topics/engineering/molar-mass" title="Learn more about molar mass from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar mass</a> of the electrode, V</span><sub>M</sub><span><span> is the <a href="/topics/materials-science/density-specific-gravity" title="Learn more about molar volume from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">molar volume</a> of the active materials, S is the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/electrode-contact" title="Learn more about electrode contact from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode contact</a> area, âˆ†E</span><sub>s</sub> is the change in the steady-state potential after a discharge or charge pulse, âˆ†E<sub>Ï„</sub> is the potential change during the constant current pulse, respectively. However, it is necessary to grasp the density of each electrode material to obtain V<sub>M</sub>, which increases the computational difficulty. To address this problem, the original formula can be simplified by unit conversion:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0020" class="formula"><span class="label">(4)</span><span class="math"><span
